awd_titl_txt: SG: Microbes promote ice formation in inland waters
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent results suggest that ice formation in northern lakes, where ice cover forms seasonally, may be assisted by the presence of filamentous diatoms (microscopic plankton).  This project will explore the idea that such biological ice nucleation actually facilitates recruitment of these diatoms, which cannot swim, from lake sediments where they live through summer up to the overlying ice where they live in winter. The bottom of the ice surface is a favorable zone for them because of the light that penetrates the ice and illuminates the diatoms; that light doesn't reach the lake bottom. To test this idea, the distribution of diatoms in summer and winter will be examined across a range of lake sizes.  Who, or what, is responsible for ice nucleation will be determined using both regular microscopes and modern genome sequencing. It is unclear whether the diatoms themselves are responsible for ice nucleation, or if it might rather be the result of bacteria growing on the diatoms. This will also be investigated. Finally, the implications of this ice nucleation activity will be investigated to see if a model can be developed that is generally applicable to ice formation in lakes around the world. This is one of the first studies of the role of microbes in the formation of ice cover in freshwater ecosystems, with most previous work done in high latitude oceans. The project could uncover a new stage of the life cycle of phytoplankton and help explain why sometimes they bloom in lakes during winter.  The associated bacteria on the diatoms may also benefit from their association with the phytoplankton.  Results of this study may change classical thinking about ice as important to lake biology. 

The broader impacts of the proposed research will include a partnership with the NSF program called iEvolve with STEM. Ice covered lakes, streams and rivers are uniquely familiar to students in northwestern Ohio, although most students probably do not realize that they are lively, even in winter. A central feature of iEvolve is the integration of students in a citizen science program that reaches across the curricula of two local school districts.  Through this association, the project will involve middle school teachers as Qualified Data Collectors as part of the Ohio Credible Data Program. Under teacher supervision, students will collect samples for water quality analysis through the seasons and be directly exposed to the vitality of lakes in winter.

por.por_cntn:
Our knowledge of ecosystem processes in ice-covered lakes and rivers is lacking, reflecting a bias for studies conducted during the de facto ice-free ‘growing season’ in north temperate latitudes.  There are multiple reasons underlying this trend. Foremost, ice cover presents a genuine logistical obstacle to pursuing winter research. Likewise, ice cover can bring expectations of dormancy predicated by cold temperatures and reduced production related to lower insolation during winter.

 

Current warming trends in global climate and declining ice coverage reinforce the need to establish in-depth baseline measurements during winter. From recent winter surveys, data support directed formation of ice by assemblages of filamentous diatoms sampled from Lake Erie. It is hypothesized that biological ice nucleation facilitates recruitment of non-motile diatoms from the sediment where they reside through summer and fall to the overlying ice, thereby maintaining a favorable position for the diatoms in the photic zone.

 

To test this model, the spatial- and temporal distribution of ice nucleating activity across scales of lake size and in rivers was assessed. "Who" is responsible for the ice nucleation activity was examined using multiple approaches.

 

Freshwater ice as habitat?

An important feature of our surveys of seasonally ice-covered lakes globally has been evidence for differential partitioning of phytoplankton and bacteria to the ice-associated phase compared to the underlying water. Further, not only does there appear to be evidence supporting selective recruitment of phytoplankton to the ice, but these cells are photosynthetically competent. While it is unclear why bacteria may be recruited to ice, it is possible that partitioning of some taxa is related to cell-surface interactions with phytoplankon, the so-called phycosphere whereby bacterial growth is stimulated by products excreted from algae.

 

Rivers and lakes as important sources of ice nucleating particles

Ice nucleating particles (INP) are a neglected, but integral component of the water cycle.  This study demonstrated that rivers and lakes possess high numbers of warm temperature biological INP and that these may become airborne where they can influence regional weather. It appears that the majority of these INP are subcellular (< 0.2 µm) and possess freezing profiles similar to known fungal INPs. This differs from the freezing profile of diatom seston collected from Lake Erie suggesting different biological sources of INP in these lotic vs. lentic environments. Rivers in north temperate zones display distinct seasonality related to spring melt and run-off as well as storm frequency. Whereas biological INP may be autochthonous – and vary with succession of microbial and fungal populations in rivers, ice active cells and macromolecules originating from land can be delivered to rivers via run-off. This was reinforced through demonstration of a strong linkage between warm temperature INP abundance and river discharge suggesting a terrestrial origin for riverine INP (Fig. 1).

 

Findings from this project have additional relevance to atmospheric sciences as INP represent an unresolved aspect of the water cycle. General circulation models examine variables such as aerosols, clouds and radiative properties of clouds to predict climate. To better constrain climate predictions, sources, abundance and properties of INP are needed to appropriately represent aerosol-cloud interactions in these models. While recent efforts characterizing marine INPs are beginning to inform such models, the contribution of freshwater INPs - which may be several orders of magnitude higher abundance than their marine counterparts - has been largely overlooked.

 

Broader impacts of this project were focused on citizen science through two programs. The first builds on an ongoing "citizen science" collaboration with the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG), the goal of which is to engage Coast Guard crew members in "credible data" surveys intended to increase both temporal and spatial resolution of sampling through winter. This USCG citizen science contribution to the project was valued both in terms of public engagement and as a means of acquiring samples from a safe platform in areas that would otherwise be too dangerous due to variable ice conditions.

 

Involvement with the NSF-supported iEvolve with STEM provided another opportunity to make an impact through engagement with middle school children and citizen science. Through regular meetings with science teachers, we helped to coordinate a citizen science program for 6th grade students at Briar Middle School in Sandusky, OH. Activities included sampling trips involving 150+ 6th grade students to Mill Hollow Park, part of the Vermillion River Reservation where students participated in citizen science collecting water quality data to be contributed to the Global Learning and Observation to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program. Follow-up meetings with all students were conducted to discuss data and their interpretation.
